poem:
**Tokyo Snapshot**

In Hara Mikiko's frame,
a tryst lingers—
neon ghosts on wet streets.
Women, once shadows,
now etch their presence in silver light,
capturing whispering alleys
where history curls its smoke.
Postwar sighs,
crumpled faces,
blossoming in a newfound gaze.
Her lens, a mirror,
reflecting what was always there,
but brightly hidden.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The big picture: Hara Mikiko captures a Tokyo tryst International interest in Japanese photography has tended to focus on male photographers; a new book featuring 25 Japanese women practitioners, I’m So Happy You Are Here, aims to redress that balance. The collection takes in the history of Japanese women photographers with particular emphasis on those working from the 1950s to the 1990s. Many of the early street-photography pioneers documented the postwar realities of Japan, particularly". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
